Nazi Dinosaurs with Cannons and Machine Guns on their backs. What more do I have to say?



Dino D-Day is a humorous WWII Multiplayer FPS about what would happen if not only did Adolf Hitler's science teams brought the dinosaurs back to life, but also gave them nerve controlled weapons, the intellegence to comprehend language, ideology, nationality, and not eat their masters? You get this silly game where Dinosaurs have cannons, machineguns, their own claws and abilities, and even suicide bombing mini dinos; I'm not kidding. The game got it's start as a single player mod for Half Life 2, but it was scrapped apparantly and it's assets turned towards a multiplayer game.

There are two teams, The Allies, and the Axis. With some memebers of either having special abilities to use.

The Allies are John Hardgrave (The Leader), who uses either the M1 Garand or the M1 Carbine. His ability is when he gets three kills, he can go into a Patriotic beserk spree! Punching facists with his super fists high into the air!

Then there's Joe Spencer, he uses either a Tommy Gun or a Grease Gun, his specialty is calling in artillary strikes onto a part of the map, which is useful for either clearing a certain chokepoint of enemies, or dealing damage to critical targets.

Up next is Nigel Blythe, English Gentleman with a Shotgun, and his choice of either a rocket launcher or a flame thrower to light those jerries up!

Supporting from the rear is Ilona Vike, cute as a button but sharp as a razorblade. This Soviet Rose is the sniper of the team and utilizes her rifle, her revolver for back up, and a dead rabbit to distract certain dinos into losing control and eating, leaving them vulnerable to either Ilona herself, or her comrades.

Supporting at the front is also Camille Brun the medic, she heals nearby teammates with her special or can chuck heal oozing medpacks for teammates to gather around.

Finally, there's Trigger, the wonder dino! Liberated from the Nazi Army, Trigger is the only Dino the allies have, and he's as deadly as he is cute, getting revenge on the long long hunt from carnivores millenia ago, Trigger uses his nerve controlled, swivel mounted 30. Browning Machine Gun on Facists, wether beast or man.


The Axis forces only have three humans, being mostly comprised of Facist dinosaurs!

Kurt Streicher is a simple soldier with no abilities to speak of, Armed with his rifle, his MP40, and some grenades, he does good on the front on his own.

Karl Hissman is the more interesting German, being a falconer, he's trained explosive, suicide Pterosaurs to fall onto where ever he points at, killing anyone nearby (Did I mention you can, if lucky, lock the Pterosaur onto an enemy?). Aside from that, he serves as the team's sniper against Ilona.

The final Human is Don Graff, the Medic and Vetrinarian for the Axis war machine. be wary that even though he is a simple medic, he is armed with an STG44.

The Facist Dinos include the classic Velociraptor, who can use his speed to surprise and overwhelm enemies, and even pounce onto them to rip their throats out.

The Dilophosaurus can pick up one of the many goats (did I mention there's goats in this game?) and lunge them at enemies for damage and laughs, as well as the ability  to knock down enemies, pick them up, and toss them for a double kill!

The Desmatosuchus is a walking tank, armed with a medium but still powerful tank turrent, he can supress enemies and kill with splash damage. Be mindful that he and his spikes are big, so it's not easy to get through certain doorways.

The Stygimoloch is the Desmatosuchus, but more mobile, agile, less bulkly, and has a MG34 Machine gun instead of a cannon. He is the German Trigger.

The Microraptor can do it all! He can fly, claw people to death when they don't know it, and blind people with a deadly acid spit, while clawing them to death!

The Compsognathus, or Compy for short, is a suicide bomber dino, though small and his bomb is just a stick grenade, he is still fanatical, and with three kills from his claws, turns his grenade from a weak firecracker, to a powerful bomb that can kill many, and set others aflame!


Finally the grand daddy of them all, only avaliable on certain maps, The Tyrannosaurus Rex! You can't spawn as him, rather there's a waiting list" on the Axis team where a random player gets selected to become the Rex until either the end of the round

reviewText:
The tide of World War II is about to change. Dinosaurs have been resurrected by the Axis to be the formidable foe against the Allies. I bought this game years ago and went in thinking it was a single player first person shooter. You vs dinosaurs! Maybe I should read descriptions. Dino D-Day is a multiplayer online first person shooter set in the 1940s. There are 9 maps to choose from and a server list to find a game. You can even play offline or alone with bots and its every bit as fun.

The teams each have their own characters. I hesitate to say classes, because everyone feels unique. Sure both teams have a medic, but they're both different. Each of the 16 characters are different and relegated to humans and dinosaurs. The Axis has six dinosaur characters and three humans. The Allies have six humans and one dinosaur named Trigger. The dinosaurs have longer stamina to run around the map, so they don't run head on into gunfire from humans. Humans are weaker, but to balance it, they're smaller. The bigger the dinosaur, the more health it has. Changing between characters is easy like Team Fortress 2.

The dinosaurs all play differently and it doesn't take that long to understand how they work. Maybe 10 minutes to be effective and efficient killers. Trigger, on the Allies side plays in 3rd per-dinosaur. He can jump and use a machine gun that needs to cool down. On the Axis, there's a Stygimoloch that plays similar with a cool down machine gun. Desmatosuchus is a slow tank that takes a lot of damage, fires very slowly and murders quickly. To balance him, he's a slow mover and so wide he can't fit through normal doorways. There is a raptor that is fast, plays in first per-dinosaur, melee kills quick, can leap, a high jump and pounce with the alt fire button in the air. A bigger dilophosaurus in 3rd person that can quickly run and head ram things to death. Not just that, it can pick up one of the goats found in most maps and heave them at the Allies. Compsognathus is the smallest third person dinosaur. Because of this, you're under the sight line of most humans. Your lack of health is gained in stealth. Plus, you can simply explode at will. Its beautiful. The final dinosaur is the Microraptor that plays in first dinosaur. It has wings and while it can't fly it can flap to keep it in the air to spit acid that blinds enemies. Not just that, but it can cling to walls and ceilings. Cling, but not wall run or anything like that.

It is the gameplay diversity and the uniqueness of all characters that really set this game apart. The humans all have their own weapons that not only feel good to use, but effective too. Most of the weapons except the shotguns have iron sights with their alt fire button.

On the Allies, you have Hardgrave, with a gun, a pistol, a grenade and his bare fists to box with dinosaurs. Spencer has his primary weapon, a pistol, his fists and a sticky bomb. Lob it out, stick it to an enemy and watch as they bring it home. Piat is the heaviest human, he uses a shotgun, a rocket launcher that only holds one rocket at a time to balance it out and smoke grenade. No fists, no melee, just big damage. Vike is a sniper, with a pistol and a rabbit. Why a rabbit? Its bait. If a carnivorous (or omnivorous) dinosaur finds the rabbit, they eat, disabling them, which gives Vike time to user her sniper rifle for one dead dino. Camille is the medic of the Allies, but in Dino D-Day the medic packs are different. She throws out the pack and when her team is near the pack, they regenerate health. So she can help her team with a machine gun, luger and fists if need be. Frank is the last member of the allies, he has a machine gun, a one shot shotgun, grenades, his fists and his devilishly good looks. Over on the Axis side, you have Streicher with a gun, machine gun, stick grenade and knife. Allies use fists, sissies like the Axis use knives. Hissman is the sniper who has a luger, stick grenade and knife. He can also summon a pterodactyl to dive bomb and explode. Wolfgang is the medic of the Axis with a machine gun, luger, knife and medi-pack.

Dino D-Day has undergone a major graphics change and the artwork looks fantastic. It has an art style true to the 1940s propaganda. Ole time radio broadcasts on the main menu go a long way for making an immersive experience. The game has come a long way in three years. There are more maps and better graphics, even after all this time. The game also has taken out references to Hitler and swastikas. There are now black crosses in white circles on red banners. So it still feels like Nazi swastikas, but its not. That's still okay. It doesn't hinder the fun.

In case you haven't heard, the game uses the Source engine. So there are a lot of comparisons between this game and other Source games like Counter-Strike: Global Offense and Day of Defeat. It plays as easily as those games with a lot of freedom to tailor the controls to what you want them to be. A lot of the maps feel like they could be in CS:GO. They feel like deserts and small villas, all while having elements of dinosaurs in them.

The Axis is the red team with blue health and the Allies are the blue team with red health. It is a bit confusing in the game. I say red and blue, because of the color of their logos. There are no actual team colors. Characters have their own non team specific attire, which can make it confusing on the battle field. How does a new player know what team that player is on? If they're on your team, they have a logo floating above their head. Anything else should get shot and killed. The problem is seeing things. A lot of times the players blend in. The night maps make it difficult to see other players, which is good for a stealth advantage. Shorter dinosaurs can hide in grass.

Each of the maps has three or four modes: Deathmatch, King of the Hill, Control Points and a few maps have objectives. The objectives in those maps are pretty simple. The allies will pick up a bomb in their spawn room and set the bomb at a specific target. The bombs take a few moments to arm, then throw and then they explode after ten seconds or so. It doesn't feel like a game changer. Speaking of the spawn room, you can find unlimited health and ammo. Outside of the base, its tougher to find health. Enemies drop ammunition. Even if you're a raptor that doesn't need ammunition, by picking it up, you're denying the enemy from having it.

Some maps are designed for T-rex deathmatches. These maps have the deadly giant under Axis control. A player from the Axis is randomly selected to be the tyranical beast. As T-rex you move slowly through the streets in a third person view, using a dual machine gun that needs to cool down. The T-rex can also belt out a roar that knocks the human Allies off their feet. Not your allies, I mean 'the Allies.' Once they're off their feet, you can slowly march over to them and eat them for extra health. You'll be lucky to eat someone, it doesn't happen that often. Playing as the T-rex is a lot of fun and even playing against it is a lot of fun. Sure the rex is only on the Axis team, but its balanced to the point where its so giant that all you need to do is run to a smaller area where it can't get you. Then its forced to waste time walking around buildings through giant openings to find where the action went to.

In all, it might sound like a gimmick, but there is fun here. Not just the premise. The game feels balanced. There are a few ways to play to have your own fun. There are now dinosaurs on both teams so people don't flood to the Axis side saying, 'dinoz yay the new kittenz of the game world!' The developers have updated and upgraded the graphics. The Source engine is a great engine to play a first person shooter. The community is still playing the game. Give it a try again if its not your first time. It has been on sale for $1.

Novel in concept, somewhat generic in practice // Recommended for fans of Team Fortress 2 who want to shake it up a bit*
*Due to limited player-base, this title is recommended if on sale

+ The different dinosaur classes boast unique play-styles and are a refreshingly entertaining to play
+ Most playable characters have a special ability, and these are fun without being game-breaking; definitely adds to the experience, rather than takes away
+ For the most part, map design is excellent and encourages competitive play; there are a couple of exceptions, but they are not enough to detract from the game
+ Movement and controls are all fairly responsive and straightforward
+ Healthy stock of game-modes available for online play (and bots); nothing new or innovative, but everything works well and complements the fast pace

- Generally below-average visuals, character models, and textures
- Questionable balance between human and dinosaur lineup, and also between factions (Allies seem to have the upper hand in firepower, but almost no dinosaurs compared to the Axis powers)
- Multiplayer is not dead, but it is dwindling; one is unlikely to find more than three active servers at a time

This game is absurd, and fun to play... usually. Pitting the Allies vs the Axis in an alternate history where Germany clones dinosaurs to fuel their war effort, the Axis forces have a near monopoly on the Dinos. This doesn't mean that the Allies are any less fun to play though. Trigger, the Allies sole dino is one of the better ones, with a charge ability, and a solid machine gun to use.

Playing at the Allies is more a straightforward FPS, with relatively standard classes. There is an assault, a sniper, a medic, all the regulars, and they do quite well against the dinosaurs, to the point that with a competitive team, the Axis forces have a bit of a harder time of things. Shotguns end dinos, sniper rifles end dinos from a distance. The Allies have a clear advantage on range in general. With a female french resistance medic, and a female sniper, I am also happy to see that I can play as a woman for once in an FPS. One that isn't merely relegated to a healer or noncombat class. This is pretty rare, and most people won't care, but I think it is pretty cool. Also of note is that several classes have area of effect buffs, such as accuracy or healing, allowing small squads to become even more deadly.

Where the Allies have an advantage in range and teamwork, the Axis have a huge advantage in variety. Want to be fast and do melee? Try the Velociraptor, which can pounce, and generally kill people (if they are not killed during the feast animation) or the Microraptor, who can glide about the battlefield and spit poison. Want to bring in the big guns? Play as a Stygimolochs with a heavy machinegun or as a Spinosaurus, who is a miniature, low slung tank. On some maps you can even play as the legendary T-Rex.

Both teams are very asymmetrical, but when dealing with new players, it seems the Allies will always get the win. Learning how to move as a dino is difficult, and many of the more powerful ones are large to the point that missing them is harder than not. My favorite thing is that the Allies are not seen as a writeoff. With some games (Pirates Vikings and Knights II comes to mind) there is a clear preference for the cool" team

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText:
~Long-ish Dino D-Day Review~

Summary: Dino D-Day is a 1st/3rd Person Shooter with a relatively small player base. Do not let this fool you, though. The game itself is actually quite fun. The game is akin to the play style of TF2 and CS:GO. It offers a few different gamemodes as well as a nice array of characters to choose from (everywhere from run-n-gunners to snipers and...DINOSAURS). The best thing this game has to offer is its raw concept, dinosaurs in WW2. Let me tell you, that stays enjoyable.

Ignore the Critics: The game does have poor reviews from Metacritic and a few notably bad reviews on Steam. Don't let this deter you. These reviews were written a LONG time ago and the game has since fixed (not all but) most of the bugs that ruined gameplay.

Should You Buy?: Personally picked up the 4-pack at $3.00 coming out to 75 cents per copy (90% off). This is a more than acceptable price for the game. I would highly recommend the 4-pack when the game is on sale. Playing with friends is a blast and the DLC (Last Stand) is decent if you have some buds to play with. The DLC is definitely not necessary for you to enjoy the game.

Quick Pros:

-Playing as a dinosaur in WW2 is just as fun as it sounds.
-Really good deal when it's on sale (90% off).

Quick Cons:

-Small online community.
-Couple bugs here and there.

All in All:

8.1/10 Would Recommend (on sale...)

A ridicolous, fun and unique WW2 shooter. Unlike many games set in this time period, this one has a lot of humour to it (even i, who thinks WW2 isn't something to joke about, got quite many laughs when playing this).

As for the game, what sets it apart from most WW2 games (easy to guess with the name it has) is that it has dinosaurs. You can be a Compsognathus and sneek up on enemies, bite them to death. Or you can be the mighty Tyrannosaurus Rex and mow them down with your MG-42, or roar them down, incapacitating them and then eat them up. It's unique and hilarious.

Graphics: The graphics are not the best i've seen, but they're passable. It is obvious that it uses the quite dated source engine, but who cares?

Music: The music is quite good, it sounds pretty much what you can expect in a WW2 propaganda movie.

Overall, Dino D-Day is a unique experience that i can recommend to anyone. It's of course not as good as some other Source Multi-Player FPS's, like Team Fortress 2 or Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, but it's nothenless a fun experience. Pick it up if you have the money for it. :)

End of this review.

reviewText:
A game of truly rough n' tumble skirmishes set in the second world war. Nazis alone don't make for an edgy enough plot anymore, and zombies are a garish pink vibrating strap-on of an angle that's been utterly exhausted. Despite this, it still remains on the throne, an idea selling like hot cakes much like that decayed ol' king from warhammer 40K. So, What's next on the list? Dinosaurs? Sure, why not.

My first impressions are that the game plays rather nicely. Controlling dinosaurs and humans alike  feels fairly fluid, though the 'runts' and humans are fixed in first person while the bigger dinosaurs take third. It would be nice to have the choice if there's variation to begin with. So You've got a mix of human and late cretatious characters to play as, and each team has a fairly unique roster to offer. Unfortunately, it's the Axis that are milking this historical re-jigging for it's worth, as they have around six or seven full dino variants to pick from. Allies only have the one, and the rest of your team is comprised of pink-♥♥♥♥♥ honkeys. This alone can sap the joy out of playing as an American, bar the fact the world hates you, but I wouldn't say it presents a significant disadvantage. I suppose there's just no satisfaction in beating on a dinosaur as a dinosaur, but rather playing Godzilla and crushing the fleeing people on a whim. This is presumably why teams are reversed each round.

My main gripe with this game as it stands are the maps. They seem lackluster in design and rather sparse. Vantage points are obvious and don't really appear to be very thought out, and you can't even sling a few shells through glass windows. Overall, the game seems a tad shallow and lacking potential for interesting, engaging tactics. It's a pretty standard formula (often likened to Team Fortress 2) with nothing terribly new to offer.
Nevertheless, I can't say it isn't satisfying to flatten a few yanks using a goat flung from your gargantuan jaws, or with another yank that you'd previously managed to keel over. There's fun to be had in this game for sure, but it's a quick, silly fix of entertainment and not one of any real lasting value. Would I recommend the game? Sure, for a happy drunken hootenanny or something. It's worth a chuckle or two at the least.

This game is not complex. It is not ground-breaking. It brings nothing new to the table and honestly, when you really look at it, is just your average shooter.

Except it's extremely fun. The best kind of fun. Dumb fun. The comedy and the art style, as well as the sheer stupidty of the scenario that this game poses fits well with the fast-paced objective combat. If I had to compare this to an existing game, I'd say a Team Fortress 2 / Day of Defeat Hybrid.

When I first played this when it was a mod, it was horribly unbalanced. The Nazi's would always win. But they've fixed that in the retail release. The Allies and the Nazi's are pretty much equal (Nazi's have the most dinosaurs, while the Allies have the best guns.)

8.8/10 It's dumb, but it's solid

This was my first honest-to-noodly-appendage first person shooter, and I *loved* it. reviewText:
This game is excellent.   I looked it up on Metacritic before committing, and saw it was only 55% with lots of negativity, but I loved the concept so installed it.  Some 3 hours later I'm only stopping playing because it's now early AM and somehow the time has flown by, mostly with a big cheesy grin on my face.  Sure the graphics aren't AAA super-realistic, but that if anything adds to the appeal and the fun - the stupid, stupid fun. In what other game can you play as a veloceraptor and  hurtle round the map in a very alien-esque fashion causing mahem?  Or as a human run screaming from a tiny compy that's chasing you with a grenade strapped to its back.  Or spawn as a giant T Rex with machine guns?  Or bust out a flame thrower just when a dino thinks it has the better of you?  Or beat the stuffing out of a dinosaur with your bare fists?  Or kill someone by spitting on them and then dino-wee on their dead corpse.

Having playing this game, I say absolutely is it worth a few quid if you like quirky teamplay FPS.  The community is great and there are plenty of servers to join.

Ignore the negative reviews and try it.

reviewText:
I hadn't played a first person shooter type game since 2009, so I was a bit skeptical about picking this game up. However, I have thoroughly enjoyed this game. There are strengths and weaknesses in both groups which helps balance everything out. The levels are pretty fun and inventive and smooth to play through (though sometimes the Dinos get stuck on objects... especially the big ones!). The graphics are also very nice, and the little details that they put into the Character models are pretty cool too... the T-Rex's belly jiggles when she moves! All in all, I am very happy to have bought this game and have a lot of fun playing whether I win or lose. But... remember that this is all coming from someone who hasn't played a shooter game since 2009. So I can't compare it to other games and have no other shooter gaming experience.

As with most online shooters, your experience will vary depending on whomever is on the server at any given game. Sometimes you do well, sometimes you don't. Just keep that in mind! ^^

reviewText:
Balance is important for a game like this, and controls.  No matter how fun it is, the game needs these to be great.

Luckily, the controls are very tight and the game seems very balanced.  Each class is unique, and the dinosaurs are great to control and are more than just gimmiky, they offer great loadout options and are great for gameplay.  Furthremore, while the Nazis have dinosaur classes, the other human classes have a wide range of weaponry to counterack the dino-threat.  Playing as humans in this game is not as boring as you would think it is.

If you like TF2, then you'll really dig this game.  It feels like a TF2 with dinosaurs, as you'll often see every class from TF2 implemented in this (Save for the engineer and spy).  Whether or not you want to spend 10.00$ for a class based shooter that plays similarly to TF2(Which is free), that is up to you.  However, if you're itching for another multiplayer shooter where you can play as Nazi dinosaurs, or just looking for a really good time, then pick this game up!

Kim Jong Un Approves.

reviewText: It's a silly game, yes. But the humor is just enough to serve as the draw, not the reason to stay. Despite the complaints of many, the classes are quite well balanced, and there is a wealth of fun to be had experimenting with the dinosaurs as well as the humans; that's right, in a game with DINOSAURS, they managed to make humans fun to play as. There is a skill to each class as well: snipers have to hide well, machinegunners have to press back against those DAMN little dinoaurs, dinos without guns must combine stealth with brute force, and the little dinsaurs have to watch out for explosives or shotguns (while everyone else cowers in terror before them). There are issues with polish, but the gameplay is worth the occasionally muddy textures, and (with the current $0.99 sale) it is perfect for budget gamers; it's a Source game after all. Players used to more high-end products may scoff, but hey, dinosaurs in Battlefield are an Easter egg; here they are reality. And don't get me started on the hilarious loading screens and radio announcements on the title screen. This game has grown a lot since 2011 (when it was, admittably, not very good) and it's worth a shot for anyone. Take advantage of the sale, and hope to see you in the field (you filthy Hun!).\n\nP.S. With the recent sale, the community is ever-growing, and we would appreciate any further enlistment!

reviewText:
It's literally dinosaurs and killing Nazis, what's not to love?
Okay, seriously, if you want an FPS you can just sit down and play, and you like dinosaurs, get this. But if you already have a ton of FPSs, then I do recommend skipping it, as it really isn't anything too special. That being said though, it actually is pretty okay. It has pretty common updates, so that's a plus, as well as trading cards and achievements, if you like those. The diversity between the teams is also pretty cool, as the Allies are mostly humans, so you can play it like a generic FPS if you want, but the Axis is where the game REALLY shines. They have dinosaurs for all kinds of people. Like rushing in with a machine gun? They have that. Want to literally BE a tank? You can do that.

Although, as I mentioned earlier, it does have some flaws. Most notably, it can be pretty hard to find a populated server, and it doesn't have great graphics, if you care about that.

TL; DR:  It's actually a pretty decent game, as long as you look past the obvious flaws.

reviewText:
I have to say, this game is one of the best I've actually ever played, and It's also won my heart through being the first game I've played, and being a game of absolutely fanatastic comedic value. The learning curve is... well, gone, as there aren't really any actual tutorials, but its controls aren't much different from any other FPS.

I would like to return to the comedic value of the game.

- You get to shoot dinosaurs with guns attached to their heads.

- You get to shoot, AS A DINO, with guns on your head.

- You can either battle or BE a freakin' Nazi dinosaur.

I believe this game's main humor is in that it DOES take itself so seriously (Which I see as a joke in itself). There are some implements of humor that were meant and obvious, such as death taunts and an action a dino can do to a human when he's knocked over (Don't think too dirty here. Just a little bit). But, that's enough of the humor.

This game is smooth to play, and has rather good graphics. You can communicate with your team through a Microphone, and having a simple, FPS shooter with no extra equipment or hats or whatever is actually quite a change after some heated MMO battle.

Now for the bad part, the Cons.

The AI of this game is really, really annoying. It's either really smart, sometikmes even flanking you, or it just sits there while you snipe at it, which can be disastorous for the other team in the mode of deathmatch. Plus, sadly, over at least a year or two no new maps have ben added, and no new dinos or characters, so don't be expecting many huge updates.

Over all, I love this game, and it's taken a place in my heart as one of the best games I've ever played. I hope you find it just as well

reviewText:
This was my first honest-to-noodly-appendage first person shooter, and I *loved* it. I found learning the controls a bit tricky and the in-game help was a bit hit and miss on that front (perhaps it is geared more toward people who have fps experience rather than a beginner), but the game itself is pretty forgiving.

My chief complaint with the game is the load time - I am used to tabbing in and out of games and found I needed to do it on this one to try and look up help with the controls. Trying to tab back in? Forget about it. The screen can take a number of minutes to load again, and with quick games this can mean you're out for an entire session (your teammates *love* that).

The group I was playing with also was having a very difficult time setting up our own game with our own controls (we wanted to play in a group with a bunch of bots as our first experience with D D-D), and we never did manage to do it.

In spite of the little quibbles, this game really is a lot of fun. I laughed quite a bit at someone in the chat complaining that the gun on his dinosaur wasn't as accurate as he wanted it to be because, well, Nazi dinosaurs.

reviewText:
This one's a decent buy but just barely in my opinion. You can get it on sale for $1 and it is entertaining but I don't feel it's something that can be played for a very long time. May be wrong about that though.

Pros:
Only $1 on sale

Funny

They have a tiny dinosaur that has a stick grenade taped to it's back to suicide bomb. That falls under funny but it deserves it's own.

Cons:
Most servers seem empty, only like 3-4 populated ones.

My ping will randomly jump from ~40 to over 800, it did this in every server and turned the game into a slideshow making me a free target for the other team.

The axis gets most of the dinosaurs and the allies only get one. This wouldn't be too terrible if 2 of the axis dinosaurs weren't microscopic and a pain in the ♥♥♥ to shoot.

The teams aren't exactly mirror copies, obviously because axis gets the most dinosaurs you'd expect that. The allies have a flamethrower which the axis has no similar class for, meanwhile the axis raptor is close to an assassin since you can pounce people for a near instant kill. The most annoying part is that the classes that do exist on both sides aren't necessarily lined up. Both teams have snipers and medics for example but when your team switches you'll be something else because they're not in the same location on the selection screen.

So-So:
The graphics aren't the best but that's to be expected.

Some of the gun animations look like crap to me.

A bit odd is that some dinosaurs are 3rd person and others are 1st person.

Community, I put this hear because I couldn't get a read on them. Some of the chat seemed joking and friendly but then other times it's a flame fest I tried to ignore, and I had to turn voip off because I couldn't take the stupid conversations.

Some classes will take siginificantly more time to kill however it is easy to do constant damage where as others have a low time to kill but a longer set up and lower health. These combine to make the game very interesting. There are some issues where there are a handful of classes that give better results to skill ratio than others but seing as these classes have limitations at higher levels of play they can't quite be called OP. This game reqwards tactical and strategic thinking and team work but these aren't necessary to play at the average level of ability.
